============
ACUTE ISSUES
============
#Pulmonary Embolism
Presented with chest tightness after 3 doses of rivaroxaban 
having been ___ with DVT at OSH. Trop & BNP nl, EKG w/o R 
heart strain. Started on heparin gtt. Transitioned over to 
apixaban. LENIs performed which showed extensive clot burden 
from common femoral to greater saphenous. Observed overnight and 
stable. D/c ambulatory sat 98%. Patient counseled on need for 
alternative to hormonal birth control.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because of a pulmonary 
embolism (a blood clot in your lungs). We started you on a 
heparin drip (an IV blood thinner). You had some symptoms 
initially, but you were stable by the time you came to the floor 
and you did well over the course of the day. We repeated the 
ultrasound of your legs and saw that you did have a fairly 
extensive clot from the thigh down to your lower leg. We 
switched you over to an oral blood thinner and watched you 
overnight.

When you get home, you will need to continue taking the 
apixaban. It is 2 tablets twice daily for the first week 
(through ___ and then 1 tablet twice daily from that point on. 
We called in the prescription to your ___ pharmacy.

You will need to call your PCP and the ___ clinic to set 
up an appointment.

Things to watch out for include: shortness of breath, 
lightheadedness, passing out, chest pain, coughing up blood. If 
any of these things happen call your doctor or go to the 
Emergency Room.

It was a pleasure taking care of you.

Sincerely,

Your ___ Team
